definitions.definition: the highest part or point of something
definitions.sensetop: at the top of somethingat the topto the topto the top of somethingon the topon the top of something

examples.text: She was standing at the top of the stairs.
The title is **right at the top** of the page.
Write your name at the top.
He filled my glass to the top.
We climbed to the **very top** of the hill.
Snow was falling on the mountain tops.
He was completely bald on the top of his head.
I was out of breath when I **reached the top**.
the top of the milk *(= the cream that rises to the top of a bottle of milk)*
The wind was blowing in the tops of the trees.

definitions.definition: the upper flat surface of something

examples.text: Can you polish the top of the table?

definitions.definition: a piece of clothing worn on the upper part of the body

examples.text: I need a top to go with this skirt.
a tracksuit/bikini/pyjama top
He was **wearing a** blue hooded **top**.
She wore a pink skirt with a matching top.

definitions.definition: a thing that you put on the end of something to close it

examples.text: Where's the top of this pen?
a bottle with a screw top
He popped the top of a soda can.
We used to collect milk bottle tops for charity.

definitions.definition: the highest or most important rank or position
definitions.sensetop: at the top of somethingat the topto the topto the top of something

examples.text: They finished the season at the top of the league.
He's at the top of his profession.
We have a lot of things to do, but packing is at the **top of the list**.
The company needs to make a change at the top.
She is determined to make it to the top *(= achieve fame or success)*.
He worked his way to the top in just a few short years.
The album shot straight to the top of the charts.
The issue has recently **risen to the top** of the agenda.
I would not have gone into boxing if I didn't think I could **reach the top**.
This decision came from the top.
The company has an unusually high proportion of young people at the top.
Pay was now at the top of the employees' agenda.

definitions.definition: the end of a street, table, etc. that is furthest away from you or from where you usually come to it

examples.text: I'll meet you at the top of Thorpe Street.

definitions.definition: the leaves of a plant that is grown mainly for its root

examples.text: Remove the green tops from the carrots.

definitions.definition: used after an amount of money, time, etc. to show that it is the highest, longest, etc. possible

examples.text: It couldn't have cost more than £50, tops.
It'll take a couple of hours, tops.

definitions.definition: a person or thing of the best quality

examples.text: Among sports superstars she’s (the) tops.
In the survey the Brits come out tops for humour.

definitions.definition: a child’s toy that turns round on a point when it is moved very quickly by hand or by a string

examples.text: She was so confused—her mind was **spinning like a top**.

definitions.definition: high up/low down in the structure of an organization or a society

examples.text: These workers are at the bottom of the economic heap.

definitions.definition: in the highest position or rank in a profession or career
as loudly as possible

examples.text: She was screaming at the top of her voice.
I was shouting at the top of my voice but she couldn't hear me.

definitions.definition: to get very angry
in the least/most important position in a group of people or things

examples.text: It’s been 20 years since a British player was top of the pile.
The government is doing little to help those at the bottom of the social pile.

definitions.definition: to win a contest or an argument

examples.text: In most boardroom disputes he tends to come out on top.

definitions.definition: going to every part of a place in a very careful way

examples.text: We cleaned the house from top to bottom.

definitions.definition: completely; all over

examples.text: She was dressed in green from top to toe.

definitions.definition: to be too much for somebody to manage or deal with

examples.text: All this extra work is getting on top of him.

definitions.definition: to manage to control or deal with something

examples.text: How will I ever get on top of all this work?

definitions.definition: just guessing or using your memory, without taking time to think carefully or check the facts

examples.text: I can't remember the name off the top of my head, but I can look it up for you.

definitions.definition: on the highest point or surface

examples.text: a cake with cream on top
Stand on top and look down.

definitions.definition: in a leading position or in control

examples.text: She remained on top for the rest of the match.

definitions.definition: in addition

examples.text: Look, here's 30 dollars, and I'll buy you lunch on top.

definitions.definition: on, over or covering something/somebody

examples.text: Books were piled on top of one another.
There was a vase on top of the bookcase.
Many people were crushed when the building collapsed on top of them.

definitions.definition: in addition to something

examples.text: He gets commission on top of his salary.
On top of everything else, my car's been stolen.

definitions.definition: very close to something/somebody

examples.text: We were all living on top of each other in that tiny apartment.

definitions.definition: in control of a situation

examples.text: Do you think he's really on top of his job?
Work tends to pile up if I don’t keep on top of it.

definitions.definition: very happy or proud
done with too much acting, emotion or effort

examples.text: His performance is completely over the top.
an over-the-top reaction

definitions.definition: to go back to the beginning of a song, piece of music, etc. and repeat it

examples.text: OK, everybody, let's take it from the top.

definitions.definition: with little or no hair on the head

examples.text: He's starting to get a little thin on top *(= he's losing his hair)*.
He's going bald on top.

definitions.definition: used to talk about a person’s intelligence

examples.text: He hasn't got much up top *(= he isn't very intelligent)*.
It’s what’s up top *(= how intelligent you are)* that matters.

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 9 late Old English topp (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch top ‘summit, crest’. noun sense 10 late Old English, of unknown origin.
